title: lab2
text:
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.1     ✔ readr     2.1.4
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
✔ ggplot2   3.4.2     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
✔ purrr     1.0.1

✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(dplyr)
library(socviz)
library(lubridate)
library(geofacet)


Attaching package: 'geofacet'

The following object is masked from 'package:socviz':

    election

library(ggthemes)


unemp_house_prices <- read_csv(
  'https://bcdanl.github.io/data/unemp_house_prices.csv')

Rows: 25704 Columns: 5
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (1): state
dbl  (3): unemploy_perc, house_price_index, house_price_perc
date (1): date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

adjust_labels <- as_labeller(
  function(x) {
    case_when(
      x == "New Hampshire" ~ "N. Hampshire",
      x == "District of Columbia" ~ "DC",
      TRUE ~ x
    )
  }
)


dat08 <- filter(unemp_house_prices, ymd(date) > ymd('2008/01/01'))

ggplot(data = filter(unemp_house_prices, ymd(date) > ymd('2008/01/01')), aes(x = ymd(date), y = unemploy_perc)) +
  geom_area(fill = 'blue3') +
  geom_line() + 
  scale_x_date(breaks = ymd("2009/01/01","2011/01/01","2013/01/01","2015/01/01","2017/01/01"),
               labels = c("'09","'11","'13","'15","'17")) +
  facet_geo(~state, labeller = adjust_labels)





election_panel <- read_csv(
  'https://bcdanl.github.io/data/election_panel.csv')

Rows: 18944 Columns: 10
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (6): state, state_po, county_name, id, candidate_DEMOCRAT, candidate_REP...
dbl (4): year, county_fips, pct_DEMOCRAT, pct_REPUBLICAN

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

mp <- county_map



dat <- left_join(mp, election_panel)

Joining with `by = join_by(id)`


Warning in left_join(mp, election_panel): Detected an unexpected many-to-many relationship between `x` and `y`.
ℹ Row 1 of `x` matches multiple rows in `y`.
ℹ Row 1 of `y` matches multiple rows in `x`.
ℹ If a many-to-many relationship is expected, set `relationship =
  "many-to-many"` to silence this warning.

ggplot(filter(dat, !is.na(year))) + 
  geom_polygon(aes(x = long, y = lat, group = group, fill = pct_DEMOCRAT), color = "grey60") +
  coord_fixed() +
  theme_map() +
  facet_wrap(~year)

title: lab3
text:
nyc_flights <- read_csv(
  'https://bcdanl.github.io/data/nyc_flights_grouped.csv')

Rows: 336776 Columns: 7
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (3): carrier_full, origin, dest
dbl (4): month, day, dep_time, arr_time

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

dat <- nyc_flights %>% 
  group_by(carrier_full) %>% 
  summarise(n = n())

dat$carrier_full <- fct_reorder(dat$carrier_full, dat$n)

ggplot(dat, aes(x = carrier_full, y = n, fill = carrier_full)) +
  geom_bar( color = 'white', stat = 'identity') +
  coord_flip() +
  geom_text(aes(x = carrier_full, y = n, label = n),nudge_x = .2, nudge_y = 5000, color = 'black' )+
  theme_wsj() +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c('Delta' = 'red', 'American' = 'red')) +
  guides(fill = 'none')

title: Midterm Presentation
text:
Houses in California can range from a few thousand dollars to hundreds of millions. If we look at the median price for each “block”, we can use a data set which is less skewed. It is interesting because of the range of prices, we might be able to find a model which can explain the relationship between median house cost and the attributes of the houses. So, can we find a model that can predict house cost?



Looking at a map of the houses in California with information on the house price and population, we can see that areas close to the coast, like LA and San Francisco, have a higher cost while more inland areas have a lower cost.








Since we are dealing with ordered pair data for location, it might be important to create a new variable which represents the distance to the coast. This could be obtained using Tableau.



Our model will most likely use a linear model.



We could use modified data which could be represented as proportions or percentages. For example, we have totalRooms and totalBedrooms variables. If we consider a variable of percentage of rooms which are bedrooms, the numbers would be better represented. We could expect more expensive houses to have lower percentage of bedrooms compared to cheaper houses.

title: Team Project
section: 1 US county map of climate change belief in 2018
text:
1 US county map of climate change belief in 2018
  Estimated percentage who think that global warming is caused mostly by human activities

cc_belief_county <- read_csv(
  'https://bcdanl.github.io/data/cc_belief_county.csv'
)


legend_title <- ""

ggplot(data = cc_belief_county) +
  geom_polygon(aes(long, lat, group = group, 
                   fill = human2018),
               color = "grey", size = 0.1) +
  coord_map("bonne", parameters = 41.6) + 
  scale_fill_gradient(legend_title, 
                      low='#0057e7', 
                      high='#d62d20') +
  theme_map() + 
  theme(legend.position="right") +
  labs(caption = "Data source: Yale Climate Change Communication")
